author: By Ellen Barry and Hilary Swift
title: Fifty Years Later, the Orphans of Flight 723 Return to the Scene
description: A Vermont woman spent years tracking down men and women who lost their parents in the same 1973 plane crash. Would they answer her questions about loss?
content: At the age of 58, stuck in her house through the long nights of the coronavirus pandemic, Michelle Brennen started to spend more and more of her time thinking about the worst thing that had ever happened to her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Georgia Prosecutor Sharply Rebukes House Republican Investigating Her
description: The prosecutor, Fani T. Willis, accused Representative Jim Jordan of Ohio of trying to obstruct her prosecution of the racketeering case against Donald J. Trump and his allies.
content: The district attorney leading a criminal case against Donald J. Trump and his allies in Georgia accused Representative Jim Jordan of Ohio of trying to obstruct her prosecution of the case in a sharply worded letter she sent on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Apple’s Market Value Falls By Billions On Worries About China Crackdown
description: Shares in the tech giant fell for a second day following reports that Beijing would bar government workers from using iPhones.
content: Shares in Apple, the world’s most valuable public company, continued to tumble on Thursday after a report that China would extend a ban on iPhones for government workers. The company is on track to lose $200 billion of market value, with shares falling about 6 percent over two days to roughly $175 as investors react to a potential threat in one of its biggest markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Contagious Corruption of Ken Paxton
description: The most important political trial of the year is taking place in Texas.
content: Let’s talk about leadership again. Last week, I wrote about Vivek Ramaswamy and the power of unprincipled leaders to exploit civic ignorance. This week, I want to address the power of leadership to shape character and the problem of corruption in the era of Trump. And for this discussion, we’ll turn to Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: The Deadpan Laureate of American Art
description: Ed Ruscha, intrepid explorer of language and image, prefigured a digital culture of words on the move. A retrospective at MoMA shines new light on his groundbreaking career: the books, the paintings, the room made of chocolate.
content: In the beginning was the word; the image, with all its troubles, came later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Soller
title: The Fashion Designer Making Art Out of Offcuts
description: Tomo Koizumi, known for his voluminous ruffled dresses, ventures into a new creative arena: painting.
content: BEFORE THE JAPANESE fashion designer Tomo Koizumi started making giant ruffled dresses out of neon-bright polyester organza — sometimes up to 90 yards of it for a single gown, worn by singers like Lady Gaga and Sam Smith — he spent nearly a decade in obscurity creating costumes for local performers, many of whom worked in Tokyo’s underground queer nightlife scene. Before that, Koizumi, 35, studied sculpture, painting and drawing at Chiba University, in the suburb where he grew up, hoping to become a children’s art teacher. Last summer, the gallerist Yukiko Mizutani heard him talk about his background on television and sought out the designer, one of fashion’s rising talents, to tell him that he should try being a visual artist himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: How Does a Best-Selling Author Name Her Characters?
description: Lisa Jewell puts a great deal of thought into the monikers she chooses for the people who populate her books. Here are her rules of thumb.
content: Lisa Jewell was walking her dog near her home in London when she caught a glimpse of a man standing at a bay window inside a scruffy stucco building. Suddenly she knew she wanted to write about him — or a character inspired by him — in her 21st book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Man Tried to Travel the Atlantic in a Hamster Wheel, U.S. Says. Again.
description: The man, Reza Baluchi, 51, was charged Tuesday in connection with the attempted voyage from Florida to London, cut short when the authorities caught up with him off the coast of Georgia last month.
content: As Hurricane Franklin was barreling toward the Eastern United States last month, the United States Coast Guard, preparing off the coast of Georgia, encountered another unexpected phenomenon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: A Fashion ‘Prodigy’ Makes a Big Debut. No Pressure.
description: With his new post at Helmut Lang, can Peter Do bring the cool minimalism of the 1990s back to American fashion?
content: Peter Do held up a pair of Helmut Lang jeans by their pockets, pulling them against his waist. The denim was off-white, splattered with white paint and softened with age. I’d already reached out to feel the fabric, pinching it between my fingers, when Mr. Do said that he’d never washed them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Hurtes and Rachel Chaundler
title: Spain’s Female Soccer Players Strike Over Wage Dispute
description: The season was scheduled to begin on Friday, but the players refused to play after talks with the league brought no agreement. The dispute comes amid a debate over sexism and soccer in Spain.
content: Female soccer players in Spain are going on strike as the club season begins, representatives from several players’ unions confirmed on Thursday, as a dispute over conduct by the head of the country’s soccer federation widened into a fight with the soccer clubs over pay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Pelosi Pushes Back on Calls for Feinstein to Resign
description: The longtime Democratic leader, who has served in the House for close to four decades, also left the door open to running again.
content: Former Speaker Nancy Pelosi defended Senator Dianne Feinstein for remaining in office after a series of health issues, dismissing concerns about Ms. Feinstein’s continued ability to serve as a sexist double standard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Amerikatsi’ Review: A Prisoner in His Homeland
description: The actor-director Michael Goorjian explores the urge to reconnect with one’s roots in this movie about an American who moves to Soviet Armenia.
content: In the late 1940s, the Soviet Union invited Armenians living abroad to resettle in Soviet Armenia. In “Amerikatsi,” the actor-director Michael Goorjian imagines one such journey and finds an unusual way to express the aching urge to reconnect with one’s roots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurel Graeber
title: They’re Tiny, They’re Toony, They’re Packing Off to Uni
description: In the reboot “Tiny Toons Looniversity,” Babs, Buster and the others from the original 1990s series head to college to learn how to be funny in 2023.
content: First-year college students everywhere are now adjusting to campus life. Few, however, have to choose between classes like Banana Peel Placement and Whoopie Cushion Alternatives. Or suffer the crash of anvils on their heads when they give wrong answers. Or petition for a change in roommates by arm-wrestling the dean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: These Are the Best French Fries in New York City
description: Great fries take time, effort and a lot of space.
content: There are many good things to eat at Libertine, a new French bistro in the West Village that I reviewed this week. But there’s one French-bistro standby you will not find there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Queens
description: This week’s properties are in South Harlem, Washington Heights and Middle Village.
content: A two-bedroom, two-bath, approximately 1,317-square-foot condo with wide-plank oak floors, large windows, a kitchen with a vented range, an en suite primary bedroom with a walk-in closet, a vented washer/dryer, central air-conditioning, and an 870-square-foot private roof deck with a water hookup, gas grill and wood-burning fireplace, on the top floor of a 12-story doorman building with a porter, live-in superintendent, shared roof deck, second-floor terrace, children’s play area and bike racks. Jennifer Corcoran, Elizabeth Knee and Sargis Mosyan, CORE, 732-682-7871; corenyc.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Philanthropies Pledge $500 Million to Address Crisis in Local News
description: The effort, spearheaded by the MacArthur Foundation, will give grants to support newsrooms and start-ups as concern grows over the rapid disappearance of local news outlets.
content: Many major philanthropic groups have increasingly focused their attention in recent years on helping struggling local newsrooms. Now they are joining forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Police Investigating Whether Court Clerk Influenced Murdaugh Jurors
description: Lawyers for Alex Murdaugh said the clerk had told jurors not to be “fooled” by his defense before he was convicted of murdering his wife and son.
content: The police in South Carolina said on Thursday that they were investigating whether a court clerk improperly communicated with jurors who later convicted Alex Murdaugh for the murder of his wife and son in one of the most famous criminal trials in the state’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Hello Dankness’ Review: Through the Looking Glass
description: The video artists known as Soda Jerk explore life in the United States from 2016 onward with an oddball assemblage of pop culture clips.
content: In the pop-culture universe deconstructed — and reconstructed — in “Hello Dankness,” the Ninja Turtles parse the Pizzagate conspiracy theory, Nancy from “A Nightmare on Elm Street” has lost sleep over the end of Bernie Sanders’s 2020 presidential campaign and a “Home Alone”-era Macaulay Culkin spends his pandemic watching “Tiger King.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: Australian Punters Are Putting a New Spin on Football
description: The tricky curves and crafty bounces of their kicks, honed by Australian football and rugby, have changed the way punt returners are coached.
content: On a cloudy, gusty morning last month, three dozen students, teachers, construction workers, electricians and bartenders wore helmets and shoulder pads and boomed torpedoes, banana kicks and drop punts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: New Jersey Failed Veterans at Pandemic-Ravaged Nursing Homes, U.S. Says
description: A scathing Justice Department report found that care at the state facilities was so poor that it violated residents’ constitutional rights and led to a rash of deaths.
content: The care given to military veterans at two state-run nursing homes in New Jersey ravaged by the coronavirus was so poor that it violated residents’ constitutional rights, according to a U.S. Department of Justice report released Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Exports Fall for Fourth Straight Month
description: New data on trade showed continuing declines in both overseas sales and imports, signs of China’s economic struggles.
content: The value of China’s exports to the world dropped 8.8 percent in August from a year earlier, the government announced on Thursday, marking the fourth month in a row of sliding overseas sales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allison McCann, Claire Cain Miller, Margot Sanger-Katz and Amy Schoenfeld Walker
title: Did You Try to Get an Abortion in the Past Year? We Want to Hear From You.
description: As part of our coverage of abortion access, we are looking for people to share their experiences.
content: We are journalists who have been covering the changes to abortion access across the country since the overturning of Roe v. Wade in June 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Amid Strikes, What Will This Year’s Oscar Season Look Like?
description: The delay of some big titles, like “Dune: Part Two,” has ramifications for coming releases like “May December” and “Killers of the Flower Moon.”
content: Three years after the pandemic forced the majority of Oscar season to take place on Zoom, Hollywood may be facing another circumscribed awards circuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: How the N.F.L. Used Supercomputers to Set Its TV (and Streaming) Schedule
description: The N.F.L. leaned into optimizing its 2023 schedule for TV (and streaming), turning to high-powered computers rather than football tradition to create matchups.
content: The announcement of the N.F.L.’s opening matchup is meant to be a curtain raiser for the regular season. But when this year’s season opener was announced in May, the participants were the ones who raised their eyebrows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: How Covid Affects the Heart
description: Three years into the pandemic, the short- and long-term risks are becoming more clear.
content: During the first two years of the pandemic, from March 2020 to March 2022, there were approximately 90,000 more deaths in the United States attributed to cardiovascular disease than were expected for that span of time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Thursday Briefing
description: Mexico decriminalizes abortion.
content: In a sweeping decision, Mexico’s Supreme Court struck down the federal penal code that criminalized abortion, deeming it “unconstitutional” and making abortion legally accessible in all federal health institutions across the country. It also ruled against bans on medical providers, including midwives, from performing the procedure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha Schwendener
title: The Armory Show, in a Back-to-School Edition
description: Art fairs come early, tailoring their calendars to compete with the city’s big fall gallery and museum exhibitions. A critic’s 11 favorite booths.
content: It’s back to school in the art world. The fall season, historically characterized by a deluge of new exhibitions, now includes art fairs that have tailored their schedules to coincide with the first wave of gallery and museum openings. The Armory Show, the mega-fair making its third fall appearance at the Javits Center, offers 225 galleries from 35 countries, a far cry from its humble beginnings in 1994 with art works propped on the beds at the Gramercy Hotel. (But even mega-fairs can be absorbed by larger entities: In July, London-based Frieze acquired the Armory Show and Expo Chicago.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Simon Romero
title: A Historic First for Mexico as Two Women Vie for the Presidency
description: Mexico will elect its first woman as president next year after the governing party chose Claudia Sheinbaum to square off against the opposition’s candidate, Xóchitl Gálvez.
content: Mexico’s governing party chose Claudia Sheinbaum, a former mayor of Mexico City, as its candidate in next year’s presidential election on Wednesday, creating a watershed moment in the world’s largest Spanish-speaking country, with voters expected to choose for the first time between two leading candidates who are women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Extreme Weather in Greece Traps Residents and Submerges Villages
description: Greek military forces were called in to assist the rescue efforts. At least six people in Greece and at least nine in neighboring Turkey have died this week amid torrential rains and flooding.
content: A night of heavy rainfall compounded major flooding in central Greece, leaving some villages almost completely under water on Thursday and prompting the government to deploy armed forces to help rescue residents from the worst-hit areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘My Big Fat Greek Wedding 3’ Review: N’opa!
description: Nia Vardalos is back in a noisy sequel that cedes the punchlines, and the plotlines, to the more cacophonous members of the Portokalos clan.
content: Nia Vardalos seized the movie industry’s attention two decades ago when she wrote and starred in the loosely autobiographical “My Big Fat Greek Wedding,” an indie charmer that remains the highest-grossing romantic comedy of all time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: In Schools, an Invisible Threat Becomes Clear
description: Apoorva Mandavilli, a health and science reporter for The New York Times, traveled across the country to learn how educators are preparing for the next pandemic.
content: Since joining The New York Times as a global health and science reporter in May 2020, Apoorva Mandavilli has had one subject top of mind: the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Arleen Sorkin, Soap Opera Star With a Claim to Batman Fame, Dies at 67
description: Her “Days of Our Lives” character provided a rare burst of daytime-drama comedy. She was later the voice of Harley Quinn, the Joker’s henchwoman.
content: Arleen Sorkin, an actress and comedian who created memorable characters in two decidedly different universes — the soap opera one of “Days of Our Lives” and the crime-fighting one of Batman, where her Harley Quinn became a fan favorite after she first gave her a voice in 1992 on “Batman: The Animated Series” — died on Aug. 24 in Los Angeles. She was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in September
description: Every month, Netflix adds movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of September’s most promising new titles.
content: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: Professor Hillary Clinton Goes Back to School
description: At Columbia University, the former secretary of state is teaching a class and starting an institute on global decision-making. Donald Trump barely gets a mention.
content: It was 20 minutes into the first class of the semester when a professor of foreign policy at Columbia University halted the lecture. “I see the phones, and I see the cameras,” she said. “This is not a Taylor Swift concert.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and John Koblin
title: Warner Bros. Suspends Deals With Top Show Creators
description: The move, which affected star writers like Mindy Kaling and J.J. Abrams, is an escalation of the standoff between Hollywood studios and the Writers Guild of America.
content: When television and movie writers went on strike in May, studios quickly suspended certain first-look deals — mostly those for lesser-established writers. Star show creators like Mindy Kaling and J.J. Abrams were kept on the payroll. Worried about keeping them happy, even during a walkout, studios left their multimillion-dollar deals alone, shielding them from the pain of the strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hisako Ueno and Ben Dooley
title: Japanese Talent Agency Admits Founder Preyed on Boys in Its Care
description: A new report confirmed hundreds of cases of sexual abuse going back five decades by Johnny Kitagawa, a giant in the world of J-Pop who died in 2019 without ever facing any charges.
content: The president of one of Japan’s most influential entertainment agencies resigned after an independent investigation confirmed the company’s founder, Johnny Kitagawa, had sexually abused young men in his care since the 1970s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir and Mike Ives
title: India’s Preparations for G20 Must Also Account for Monkeys
description: For New Delhi, monkeys are a minor problem compared with poverty and pollution, but the government doesn’t want them stealing the spotlight when world leaders arrive.
content: If you’re ever in New Delhi and think you hear a monkey, don’t assume it’s a monkey. It could be a professional monkey noise impersonator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Hurricane Lee Strengthens to a Category 5 Storm, but Its Eventual Path is Unclear
description: The Atlantic hurricane will cause rip currents in the Caribbean and on the East Coast of the U.S. starting Friday. Experts, however, don’t know for sure where the storm is going.
content: Hurricane Lee has grabbed the attention of forecasters and social media this week as the rapidly intensifying storm moves west across the open waters of the Atlantic.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Biden Says He Will Nominate Former F.A.A. Deputy to Lead Agency
description: The president’s selection, Michael G. Whitaker, served as the No. 2 official at the Federal Aviation Administration during the Obama administration.
content: President Biden announced on Thursday that he planned to nominate Michael G. Whitaker, who served as the No. 2 official at the Federal Aviation Administration during the Obama administration, to become the agency’s next permanent leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Grizzly Bear That Had Killed a Woman Is Euthanized After Breaking Into a House
description: The 10-year-old female bear responsible for the earlier fatal attack near West Yellowstone, Mont., had also injured a person near an Idaho state park in 2020, officials said.
content: A grizzly bear that killed a woman on a Montana trail in July and injured a person near an Idaho state park in 2020 was euthanized after it broke through the kitchen window of a house this month, Montana wildlife officials said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: How the Pennsylvania Fugitive Scaled a Prison Wall and Escaped
description: Surveillance video released by the police shows the convicted killer wedging himself between two opposing walls and propelling himself upward.
content: Place one hand on the wall in front of you, and then put the opposite foot on the wall behind you. Repeat with your other limbs until you have wedged yourself between the two walls. Easy does it. Now, start “walking” up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: ‘I’m OK, but Things Are Terrible’
description: The mystery of Americans’ economic negativity.
content: If President Biden loses his bid for re-election, a key factor will be the widespread perception that the economy is doing badly on his watch. Poll after poll shows Americans rating economic conditions as very bad and giving Biden very low approval for his economic management.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Joyce Carol Oates’ Review: What’s She Thinking?
description: This generic documentary, subtitled “A Body in the Service of Mind,” is so fixated on canonizing its subject that it skirts around what makes her so intriguing: her peculiar and provocative ideas.
content: It’s a modern-day tragedy that some people may know the writer Joyce Carol Oates primarily for her online presence — on social media, she has posted a picture of her foot oozing with blisters, and regularly voiced inflammatory opinions. It’s odd — and oddly fascinating — behavior for such a literary heavyweight, one whose six decades of novels, short stories, essays and more have triggered fascinating debates about the intersection of violence, sexuality, race and womanhood (among other dark, distinctly American subjects).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: A Three-Legged Bear Walks Into a Bar
description: Tripod, a three-legged bear, has become a local celebrity in a Central Florida neighborhood, drinking a family’s White Claws and eating its shrimp meal.
content: A three-legged black bear wandered onto the patio of a house in Florida. He trudged by the pool. He ambled up to a fish tank and gnawed on a container of guppy food. Then he went for the refrigerator, grabbed two cans of White Claw hard seltzer and tossed away a third.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In Mexico, a New Space for Hot Pink Wicker Lamps and Spiky Bowls
description: Plus: a farm-to-table pub in the Cotswolds, horse-themed tableware — and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: I have quite dry skin and eyes, so I need all the moisture possible. I use a Neostrata Matrix Support day cream and Intensive Eye Therapy; then when I shower, I use Dermafix DermaPolish + Activated Charcoal. I feel like I have great skin now, but it’s been a journey to maintain it. Dr. Fatima Bhabha, my doctor in Johannesburg who specializes in aesthetic medicine, really got me thinking that I need to follow a routine and use sunscreen. I use this Italian brand, BioNike Defence Sun 30 Mineral Cream. On my body, I use Nivea Men All Seasons Moisture Body Cream, and because I have such dry skin I always use aloe vera to moisturize. My grandmother always had the plants outside and would slather me with aloe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: This Artist’s Next Project Has Her ‘Terrified.’ That’s the Point.
description: An upcoming exhibition at the New Museum by Jade Kuriki-Olivo, also known as Puppies Puppies, puts a microscope on her experience as a trans woman.
content: Jade Kuriki-Olivo’s guided tour through her apartment on the Lower East Side ended in the bedroom, where the performance artist spends most of her time. Tropical vines crawled along the walls and into a giant lantern hanging opposite a tapestry of green synthetic fur. She burned incense and described her room above a busy Greek restaurant as a sanctuary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: ‘The Devil They Know’: McConnell’s Health Issues Worry Democrats
description: The legislative stances of the G.O.P. leader and his usual opponents are aligned on Ukraine, spending and impeachment as he faces mounting health scrutiny.
content: Senator Chuck Schumer was downright effusive when asked about Senator Mitch McConnell’s health status after the Kentucky Republican’s second frozen moment before television cameras last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: N.Y.C. Schools Reimagine Reading This Fall to Fix Dismal Literacy Rates
description: A new semester means a whole new way of teaching reading at hundreds of schools in the nation’s largest school system.
content: From Brooklyn to the Bronx, posters encouraging students to “skip the tricky word” or “look at the picture” as they read have been pulled from bulletin boards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Matthew Goldstein
title: Fourth Top FTX Executive Pleads Guilty Ahead of Sam Bankman-Fried Trial
description: Ryan Salame, a former FTX executive, pleaded guilty to charges linked to the sweeping fraud case against Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the failed cryptocurrency exchange.
content: Ryan Salame, a former top executive at the cryptocurrency exchange FTX, pleaded guilty on Thursday to criminal charges linked to the sweeping fraud case against FTX’s founder, Sam Bankman-Fried, a move that raises the pressure on Mr. Bankman-Fried ahead of his trial next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Covid Continues to Rise, but Experts Remain Optimistic
description: An uptick in hospitalizations and deaths persists, but the numbers are relatively low and new vaccines are around the corner.
content: Jill Biden, the first lady, tested positive for Covid-19 on Monday. Governor Kathy Hochul of New York has announced that the state will send high-quality masks and rapid tests to school districts that request them. Already, schools in Kentucky and Texas have closed, citing widespread respiratory illness among students and staff.

title: Abortions After Dobbs
description: The number of legal abortions has held steady, if not increased, after the Supreme Court’s ruling.
content: After the Supreme Court struck down Roe v. Wade last year, it looked like the number of abortions would soon plummet across the country. But new estimates suggest that has not happened. The number of legal abortions has held steady, if not increased, nationwide since 2020, our colleagues Amy Schoenfeld Walker and Allison McCann reported today.

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: In ‘Swing State,’ Rebecca Gilman Sees a Troubled World
description: In her Off Broadway drama, which had an acclaimed run in Chicago, the playwright looks for hope to outweigh despair in a fractious, anxious time.
content: The playwright Rebecca Gilman moved away from small-town Alabama long ago, but a soft Southern lilt still shapes her words. In all the years she lived and worked here in her adopted city of Chicago, she remained immune to its Bill Murray accent. The broad tones of nearby Wisconsin have likewise left no mark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Patricia Caulfield, 91, Dies; Battled Warhol Over Use of Her Photograph
description: She sued the pop artist while she was executive editor of Modern Photography. She later traveled the world as a nature photographer.
content: Patricia Caulfield, who during her time as a top editor at Modern Photography magazine in the 1960s successfully sued Andy Warhol for misappropriating a picture she made of hibiscus blossoms, then left the publication to become an acclaimed nature photographer, died on July 16 in Manhattan. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Ronen Bergman
title: U.S. Seized Iranian Oil Over Smuggling Incident That Escalated Tensions in Gulf
description: The apprehension of the ship, the Suez Rajan, came after a group opposed to Iran raised accusations of sanctions violations last year.
content: The United States government has seized nearly one million barrels of Iranian crude oil that it says was being smuggled to China in violation of U.S. sanctions against Iran, after it raised the threat of prosecution to get the tanker brought to American waters, newly unsealed court papers show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor, Livia Albeck-Ripka and Michael Levenson
title: Danny Masterson Is Sentenced to 30 Years to Life in Prison for Two Rapes
description: The “That ’70s Show” actor was found guilty in May of raping two women in the early 2000s.
content: Danny Masterson, the actor best known for his role in the sitcom “That ’70s Show,” was sentenced to 30 years to life in prison on Thursday for the rapes of two women when he was at the height of his career more than 20 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Tibetan Treasure Trove Leaves Manhattan
description: An Upper East Side collector is sending her art to a museum in Minneapolis.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll go into a room in a Manhattan apartment that will be recreated, intact, in a museum in Minneapolis. We’ll also get details on why Donald Trump’s next defamation trial will go directly to the damages he should pay the writer E. Jean Carroll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Vanessa Friedman
title: Head of Luxury Goods Maker Kering Buys Majority Stake in Talent Agency CAA
description: The deal for Creative Artists Agency by François-Henri Pinault’s family office reflects the growing convergence of celebrities and fashion.
content: In a deal that shows the ever-growing convergence of fashion and fame, François-Henri Pinault, the French billionaire and chief executive of the luxury goods company Kering, said on Thursday that his family office had bought a majority stake in one of Hollywood’s biggest talent agencies, Creative Artists Agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Jill Biden Tests Negative for Coronavirus
description: The first lady’s brief Covid episode had threatened to upend President Biden’s trip to a Group of 20 summit in India.
content: Jill Biden, the first lady, tested negative for the coronavirus on Thursday, the White House said, putting an apparent end to a minor health scare that had threatened to upend President Biden’s trip to a Group of 20 summit in India.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Mashberg
title: A Dozen Looted Artifacts Are Returned to Lebanon
description: Some of the pieces were seized from the Metropolitan Museum of Art and others from the New Jersey storage unit of a Lebanese collector and dealer.
content: New York and federal authorities handed back 12 looted antiquities valued at $9 million to Lebanon on Thursday, including three objects removed from the Metropolitan Museum of Art last year during a flurry of multimillion-dollar seizures there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Blatt
title: The Plight of the N.F.L. Running Back
description: A combination of factors has devalued one of the marquee positions in all of American sports.
content: N.F.L. running backs, once the face of many teams, have fallen so far in relative value over the last few decades that it has amounted to a public demotion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexa Brazilian and Kyoko Hamada
title: The Hyperreal Wonders of Glacé Fruit
description: A time-consuming, glossy confection beloved by 16th-century royalty is making an unlikely return.
content: INSIDE A GILDED Rococo room on the Avenue Montaigne in Paris, candied fruits dangled from winterberry tree branches. Hand-sewn to the limbs with waxed twine by the food artist Imogen Kwok and her team, the sugar-confit-dipped pears, clementines and cherries resembled orbs of glass and were clipped off by guests with bonsai scissors for an interactive dessert course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Cain
title: Grandma’s Pearls, in Fresh Fashion
description: Brides — and grooms — are clamoring to incorporate pearls into their wedding looks in modern ways.
content: Dri Buono Patel already had her wedding jewelry — diamond cluster earrings, to complement her satin off-the-shoulder gown — picked out for months, but just weeks before the ceremony, she fell in love with pearls. When she saw a pair of drop earrings featuring South Sea pearls, she decided to change her entire jewelry look on the spot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: The American Renaissance Is Already at Hand
description: As China Stumbles, Ohio Rebounds.
content: Two megatrends have shaped American life since the 1980s: The rise of China and the hollowing out of American industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Weekender
description: Burning Man’s muddy aftermath. Also: public pools in Paris, and where the universe began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hunter Harris
title: A Dishy Tell-All About Emily Weiss’s Glossier
description: Marisa Meltzer’s “Glossy” recounts the millennial makeup company’s dewy rise and unglamorous plateau.
content: A Glossier brick and mortar opened in my neighborhood last fall, and because that neighborhood is Williamsburg, I could comfortably declare it to be the brand’s time of death. No longer the experiential playscape of dreamy makeup delights, Glossier has reached its logical conclusion: patrons waiting an annoyingly long time among intermittent groups of teens to buy $18 eyebrow gel. Here lies Glossier, the millennial pink tombstone’s black etching would read, makeup for pretty people. That the Williamsburg Glossier is neighbored by retail stores for Parachute (bedding), Mejuri (jewelry) and Warby Parker (glasses) does not feel coincidental; all the formerly online-only direct-to-consumer brands are arranged on North Sixth Street in a neat little row.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: Buying Is Just the Beginning. What Does It Really Cost to Own a Home?
description: A new study adds it all up over the typical length of homeownership. The result? Utilities will cost more than your down payment.
content: You’ve got your down payment and you’ve been approved for a mortgage. What a relief. But now the real spending begins. If you want to know the actual price of owning a home, throw in closing costs, moving expenses, homeowner’s insurance, private mortgage insurance (P.M.I.) if required, property taxes, home maintenance and utilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Springsteen Postpones September Shows to Be Treated for Peptic Ulcer Disease Symptoms
description: The 73-year-old singer’s medical advisers made the decision to postpone the shows, according to the announcement.
content: Bruce Springsteen announced on Wednesday evening that he would postpone performances scheduled with the E Street Band for the rest of September, as he is treated for symptoms of peptic ulcer disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Craig Singleton
title: China’s Military Is Going Global
description: Beijing is laying the groundwork to challenge U.S. forces around the world.
content: At Cambodia’s Ream Naval Base, China is nearing completion of what U.S. officials suspect will be its first overseas military outpost in the Indo-Pacific region. This represents a major evolution in Beijing’s regional defense strategy. Beyond facilitating Chinese military adventurism in the South China Sea, the new base could provide the People’s Liberation Army, or P.L.A., with a staging ground to monitor and influence vital maritime routes like the Malacca Strait, through which an estimated 40 percent of the world’s trade flows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘The First Year’ Review: Allende’s Rule in Chile
description: The French-language version of a 1971 documentary by Patricio Guzmán is an extraordinary document of a nation in transition.
content: A few years before Patricio Guzmán directed his tripartite masterpiece, “The Battle of Chile,” about the events leading to the C.I.A.-backed military coup that toppled the socialist government of President Salvador Allende in 1973, the Chilean filmmaker made “The First Year”: an account of the inaugural 12 months of Allende’s rule. Guzmán traveled through Chile, interviewing the working class about Allende’s socialist policies and accumulating a crackling portrait of hope and incipient change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Rotting in the Sun’ Review: Instagram, Real
description: Sebastián Silva’s satirical thriller blurs the line between reality and illusion that fuels social media.
content: In his new movie, the Chilean filmmaker Sebastián Silva plays a version of himself locked in a self-loathing spiral. Mired in a creative pit, Sebastián is snorting drugs in his Mexico City apartment, reading E.M. Cioran’s “The Trouble With Being Born” and doing web searches for “suicide by Pentobarbital.” In need of a change, he travels to a bacchanalian gay beach, where he meets the writer and Instagram influencer Jordan Firstman (also playing a refracted version of himself). It’s not long before the ebulliently opportunistic Jordan pitches a show: “‘Curb Your Enthusiasm,’ but positive.” Eventually, Sebastián invites him to his place in the city for some writing sessions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: The Problem With ‘Elites’ May Not Be What You Think It Is
description: A new book aims to save the left from itself.
content: Elitism is a frequent target of criticism, especially in politics. Historically, Americans haven’t liked elitists. They don’t appreciate the hoity-toity who look down on everyone else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Researchers Identify Jews Aided by Catholics in Nazi Era as Pope Was Silent
description: The names were found in documents recently studied by the Vatican, but historians say they don’t change the fundamental understanding of the church’s actions during the war.
content: A group of historians convened by a research institution of the Vatican announced on Thursday the discovery of documents naming thousands of Jews in Rome who received safe haven in Catholic convents and monasteries during the Nazi occupation of the Second World War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: A French Welcome for Woody Allen, Louis C.K. and Johnny Depp
description: Under fire in America, Mr. Allen made his 50th film in and around Paris, where he was able to secure a deal, despite the sexual abuse accusations against him.
content: Woody Allen has described his new movie, “Coup de Chance,” as a “poisonous romantic thriller.” It made its debut at the Venice International Film Festival on Monday, and will be released on Sept. 27. But American moviegoers won’t be able to see it in theaters unless they happen to be visiting, say, Paris or Marseille.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Gabon Military Says Deposed President Is Free to Travel Overseas
description: Before Ali Bongo Ondimba was ousted in late August, he and his family had ruled over the oil-rich central African state for more than half a century.
content: Ali Bongo Ondimba, who was deposed as president of Gabon last week in a coup that ended his family’s decades-long grip on power in the central African nation, is no longer subject to house arrest and is free to leave the country, the ruling military junta has said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roque Raquel Salas Rivera and Anne Boyer
title: Poem: From ‘Algarabía’
description: A journey through a fantastical projection of Puerto Rico.
content: Roque Raquel Salas Rivera’s epic poem “Algarabía” follows the journey of its protagonist, Cenex, on the Isle of Algarabía, a fantastical projection of Puerto Rico, referred to in the poem as ELA (Estado Libre Asociado) and in the English translation as the Commonwealth, Puerto Rico’s official colonial status. “Algarabía” is a Spanish word rooted in “Al-arabiyya” or Arabic, which came to mean the uproarious noise made when many voices are speaking at once. This fragment is from a moment in the epic in which the voices of a transgender chorus come together to help the hero through his journey. Selected by Anne Boyer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: In Escalation, Adams Says Migrant Crisis ‘Will Destroy New York City’
description: In provocative remarks at a town hall meeting, Mayor Eric Adams said that he did not “see an ending” to the migrant crisis and renewed his push for federal help.
content: In a sharp escalation over the migrant crisis, Mayor Eric Adams claimed in stark terms that New York City was being destroyed by an influx of 110,000 asylum seekers from the southern border and said that he did not see a way to fix the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Brantley
title: Confessions of a Drag Legend: Charles Busch’s Memoir Is Here, Darling
description: “Leading Lady,” a mosaic of reminiscence and self-analysis, explores the ascent of a man who’s really good at playing women.
content: Charles Busch, the celebrated male actress, Tony-nominated playwright and, most recently, exuberant memoirist, has been thinking that his bed might make a good stage. At his Greenwich Village duplex last month, he noted how the arched entrance to his blindingly white boudoir resembles a proscenium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Taking the Middle Seat on a Flight
description: Should you move over if there’s an empty chair?
content: On a recent flight, I anticipated being stuck like a sardine in my window seat. But there was only one other person in my row, sitting in the middle seat. I expected her to move over, but instead she used the aisle seat for her bag and trash. Please order that a person closest to an open seat should move over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
title: Can India’s Global Ambitions Survive Its Deepening Chasms at Home?
description: India’s hosting of the G20 summit this weekend will put its growing power on display. But its leader’s divisive religious politics threaten its rise.
content: Inside a sprawling golf resort south of New Delhi, diplomats were busy making final preparations for a fast-approaching global summit meeting. The road outside was freshly smoothed and dotted with police officers. Posters emblazoned with the image of Prime Minister Narendra Modi bore the slogan he had chosen for the occasion: One Earth, One Family, One Future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: 2 Plead Guilty in Attacks on Substations in Washington State
description: They had hatched a scheme to cut power in Pierce County and rob A.T.M.s and local businesses, leaving thousands in the Tacoma area without power on Christmas Day, prosecutors said.
content: Two men have pleaded guilty to conspiracy charges in connection with attacks on several electrical substations that left thousands of customers around Tacoma, Wash., without power on Christmas Day last year, a criminal pact that the authorities said was part of a burglary scheme to rob A.T.M.s and local businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Coach Who Won Supreme Court Case Over Prayers on the Field Resigns
description: Joseph Kennedy’s case expanded the place of religion in public life. On Wednesday, he said he would “continue to work to help people understand and embrace the historic ruling at the heart of our case.”
content: A high school football coach in Washington State who won a Supreme Court case last year over whether he could pray on the field after his public school team's games and rejoined the coaching staff this season said on Wednesday that he had resigned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Edgar Sandoval
title: Is Texas’ Busing Responsible for the Migrant Crisis Across Cities?
description: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas has run a high-profile campaign to send migrants to Los Angeles, New York and other cities. But they are a fraction of the number of new migrants boarding buses.
content: When a bus packed with migrants pulled into downtown Los Angeles in mid-June, it caused a local stir: In a city with one of the country’s largest immigrant populations, this was the first busload to arrive courtesy of the Texas governor, Greg Abbott.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From a 450-year-old Robot to Annie Ernaux
description: A selection of recently published books.
content: MANDELA: In Honor of an Extraordinary Life, by Makaziwe Mandela. (Rizzoli, $75.) This hybrid biography of Nelson Mandela, compiled by his daughter, includes personal photographs, letters, stories, journal entries and charcoal drawings to offer an intimate rendering of the South African leader’s life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: From Hoover to Nixon to Obama, Presidential Centers Call to Protect Democracy
description: A rare statement released jointly from groups representing nearly a century of presidents stresses the importance of the pillars of democracy and civility in politics.
content: A coalition representing nearly every former president from Herbert Hoover to Barack Obama issued a collective call on Thursday to protect the foundations of American democracy and maintain civility in the nation’s politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat, Carlos Lozada and Lydia Polgreen
title: The Woke Burnout Is Real — and Politics Is Catching Up
description: It’s time to start asking if the culture wars actually matter to voters.
content: Classrooms have been a key battleground in the so-called woke wars for years now. But could the debate over how schools teach history, race, gender and sexuality be coming to an end?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Household Items Can’t You Live Without?
description: An illustrator shares her love letter to a 750-square-foot roll of plastic wrap. What would you pen an homage to?
content: A hair dryer? A scissors? Microwave? Air-conditioner?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson, Shaila Dewan and Joel Wolfram
title: Prison Officials Say Human Error Played Role in Pennsylvania Escape
description: An officer who was in a watchtower is on administrative leave, as prison officials review what went wrong during Danelo Cavalcante’s escape last week.
content: Before Danelo Cavalcante crab-walked his way up and out of the Chester County Prison, launching a sprawling manhunt in the wooded suburbs outside Philadelphia, a man named Igor Bolte escaped from the same jail. Twice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Eric Krupke, Will Reid, Liz O. Baylen, Paige Cowett, Rowan Niemisto, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Alyssa Moxley
title: Why One Drug Company Held Back a Better Drug
description: Drug companies say patents spur innovation. Can they also do the opposite?
content: For decades, drugmakers have argued that patents are critical to bringing new drugs to the market. But in 2004, when a promising H.I.V. treatment emerged, Gilead Sciences decided to slow-walk its release to maximize profit on the company’s existing patents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo and Claudia Gryvatz Copquin
title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: This week’s properties are a five-bedroom in Centerport, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Medford, N.J.
content: A five-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath house built in 1995, with a front porch, an entry foyer, a center hall, a formal dining room, a living room with French pocket doors, a family room with a wood-burning fireplace and open to an eat-in kitchen, an office, an en suite primary bedroom with two walk-in closets and an attached two-car garage, on one acre. Laura Zambratto, Daniel Gale Sotheby’s International Realty, 917-822-4360; danielgale.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Tropical Storm Margot Forms in the Atlantic Ocean
description: The storm is forecast to grow into a hurricane, but posed no immediate threat to land.
content: Tropical Storm Margot formed in the North Atlantic Ocean on Thursday, becoming the 13th named storm of the 2023 Atlantic hurricane season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Victoria’s Secret Fashion Show Returns. But Not as You Knew It.
description: The lingerie brand introduces a feature-length film meant to be the final piece of its reinvention.
content: The last time Victoria’s Secret had a fashion show was 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Roiphe
title: A ‘Mirror World’ Where Leftist Disdain Feeds Right-Wing Paranoia
description: In her latest book, “Doppelganger,” Naomi Klein investigates an online underworld of conspiracies and misinformation, showing how its rise has inadvertently been fueled by political progressives.
content: Reading the leftist writer and activist Naomi Klein’s new book, “Doppelganger,” feels like falling down a rabbit hole, albeit a dazzling and erudite one. It begins with Klein’s account of being confused on social media for Naomi Wolf, the feminist intellectual turned rabid anti-vaxxer, whom Klein calls “my big-haired doppelganger.” During the pandemic, Wolf began arguing, online and in a book, that vaccines and other public health measures were a plot by a “transnational group of bad actors” to sterilize people, turn children into drones and undermine the Constitution, among many other unhinged assertions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bon Duke and Jordan Boothe
title: This Fall, Coats Hit the Floor
description: Long outerwear is the silhouette of the season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: N.F.L. Week 1 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
description: The Packers-Bears rivalry starts anew and the hyped-up Jets will be tested against the Bills in a strong slate of games.
content: There is a beautiful optimism to the start of every N.F.L. season. Just about every team believes it could be this year’s version of the 2022 Giants, who surprisingly stormed to a 9-7-1 record and the playoffs. Every newly acquired player, regardless of age or recent production, is the key to overall improvement, and every player who left was probably at the end of his utility, anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: Mother Wins $75,000 After New York Took Her Baby Over Marijuana Use
description: Chanetto Rivers’s baby was taken away after she smoked marijuana, legally, before giving birth. She sued, and won a settlement that her lawyers say is the first of its kind.
content: New York City’s child welfare agency agreed to pay $75,000 to a mother from the Bronx who had her newborn son removed after she legally smoked marijuana hours before giving birth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Sokolove
title: How Ben Sasse Became a Combatant in Florida’s Education Wars
description: As Ron DeSantis has turned public education into a political battleground, his state’s flagship university, now led by the former G.O.P. senator from Nebraska, has not remained neutral territory.
content: When the University of Florida’s president, Kent Fuchs, announced early last year that he planned to step down and a search began for a new campus leader, the school was well positioned to attract a top-tier candidate. Set on 2,000 wooded acres between Orlando and Jacksonville, U.F., as it is known, does not have the shiny reputation of some of the nation’s other big public universities, and its home city, Gainesville, doesn’t radiate the charm of, say, a Chapel Hill, N.C., or a Boulder, Colo. But it could be argued that the school is the model of what a public university should be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Howard
title: Back to School or Back to Summer? A Heat Wave Arrives Late to New York.
description: A three-day bout of extreme weather in the Northeast is sending temperatures 20 degrees higher than usual.
content: Typically, September in New York City starts to show hints of fall, with average temperatures in the 70s, as children return to school. But this week, the back-to-school season has felt more like a last gasp for summer, with a three-day heat wave sending temperatures 20 degrees higher than usual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurel Graeber
title: 81st Street Studio, a Garden of Artful Delight
description: The 3-to-11-year-old crowd can sample music, rest on scented pillows, make digital woodblock prints and study Met museum objects at this new drop-in center.
content: Heidi Holder said she had one firm rule for the design of the new children’s learning center at the Metropolitan Museum of Art: It was not going to be an “egg carton.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: In the Gritty Tenderloin, Signs of Rebirth Emerge in Small Stretches
description: The San Francisco neighborhood has become a punching bag for critics of the city, but there are reasons to hope for a better future.
content: The notorious Tenderloin. It’s a symbol of so many problems afflicting San Francisco. Homelessness, drug overdoses, retail theft, general filth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: ‘Aristotle and Dante’ Review: Texas Hold Him
description: The film “Aristotle and Dante Discover the Secrets of the Universe,” a gay teen romance set in 1980s Texas and adapted from Benjamin Alire Sáenz’s novel, is tenderhearted but meandering.
content: In the 1980s, it was nothing to wander the mall, from Spencer’s to Waldenbooks, with no direction. Alas, similar ambling takes place in the screenwriter-director Aitch Alberto’s sweet-at-heart but lukewarm indie drama about two Mexican American high schoolers coming-of-age in 1987 El Paso.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: The Secret Ingredient Your Salads Are Missing
description: Marinating tomatoes is a quick and easy way to coax out their juices and make them the perfect complement to leafy greens, Melissa Clark writes.
content: My mother loved leftover salad. No matter what a long night in the fridge had inflicted upon the lettuce and the cress, she’d pile those saturated greens onto a toasted English muffin and swear it was a better breakfast than butter and jam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Deputy Sheriff Kills 2 Teens Who Tried to Run Him Over, Officials Say
description: New York’s attorney general opened an inquiry into the fatal shooting, which occurred amid what officials said was an investigation into car thefts and burglaries.
content: A sheriff’s deputy fatally shot two teenagers in Central New York on Wednesday after they tried to run him over with a car they had stolen and then used while breaking into two smoke shops, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Old Is Workable. Depravity Is a Dead End.
description: Two dynamics will likely dominate the next presidential election.
content: Thirty-six years in the Senate, eight as vice president, nearly three in the White House — President Joe Biden has a long record to be judged by, a deep familiarity with Washington that Americans can decide to see as an asset or an impediment. But what happens in November 2024 may have significantly less to do with how he has navigated the corridors of power than with how he moves from the edge of the stage to the lectern and from subject to verb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China Is Flooding the World With Cars
description: Even as China’s other exports falter, its carmakers are seeing big increases in overseas sales, mainly for gasoline-powered models.
content: At a time when many of China’s exports are faltering and its consumers are spending less at home, the country is flooding the world with cars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Friday Briefing: A G20 Preview
description: Also, how Mattel made “Barbie” a hit.
content: The Group of 20 summit kicks off tomorrow in New Delhi, bringing together world leaders to coordinate policy for the global economy. President Biden is expected to attend, but China’s leader, Xi Jinping, and President Vladimir Putin of Russia will skip the event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: New York’s Migrant Crisis Is Growing
description: Also, a prison escape near Philadelphia. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: In a sharp escalation, Mayor Eric Adams declared that New York City was being destroyed by an influx of 110,000 migrants from the southern border. His comments, criticized by advocates for villainizing migrants for seeking a better life, underscored how the surge has become overwhelming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: 2 Senators Propose Bipartisan Framework for A.I. Laws
description: The effort by Senators Richard Blumenthal and Josh Hawley is the latest move by lawmakers to catch up with the rapidly evolving technology.
content: Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, and Senator Josh Hawley, Republican of Missouri, plan to announce a sweeping framework to regulate artificial intelligence, in the latest effort by Congress to catch up with the technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Drone Strikes Rock Russian City That Is Home to Key Military Base
description: Ukraine never acknowledges strikes on Russian soil, but the incursions are happening with increasing frequency.
content: Explosions rocked the area around one of Russia’s largest military hubs before dawn on Thursday, and local officials later said that air defenses had shot down two drones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Join the Times Climate Event With Bill Gates, Marie Kondo and Others
description: Sign up to watch the livestream and connect with online attendees about solutions to the climate crisis on Thursday, Sept. 21.
content: Climate change is an issue that stretches across borders, touching every facet of our lives. Addressing it likewise requires shifts in almost every industry and institution. On Sept. 21, The New York Times will bring together newsmakers, including innovators, activists, scientists and policymakers, for an all-day event examining the actions needed to confront climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: Reveling in Photos, Paper and Wild Cards: 5 Art Fairs to See in N.Y.C.
description: Fall art fair season has arrived, with the Armory Show, the Independent 20th Century and satellite exhibitions on display across the city.
content: Each year, the weekend after Labor Day means a spate of art fairs across New York City. The temperature (hopefully) drops; the art on display surges. Whether you’re into sprawling expositions or smaller, subversive fairs are more your speed, there is something for everyone in the burst of art on display this weekend. Here’s a guide to some of our favorites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: Dinner Recipes You’ll Be Happy to Eat Again for Lunch
description: Future you will be grateful for reheated white bean and tomato pasta and zucchini salad with feta (which has soaked up all those za’atar-y spices).
content: Despite September’s promise of fresh starts and autumnal abundance, shuffling kids back to school, commuting to an office or simply battling the end-of-summer malaise doesn’t always leave us feeling refreshed or with an abundance of time on our hands.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Have you played The Times’s latest game, Connections, yet? This week our list of recommended books resembles a particularly literary version of that puzzle, with two girlhood memoirs by former Ivy League presidents, two satirical Irish novels, two memoirs of art and trauma, and three books with no clear relation to one another: a romance novel, a warning against the dangers of processed foods and a biography of the early Chinese American movie star Anna May Wong. Happy reading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Kiang
title: At Venice Film Festival, Trapped Women and Controlling Men
description: This year’s lineup includes films from Sofia Coppola, Yorgos Lanthimos and Bradley Cooper in which female characters squirm under the thumbs of egocentric men.
content: The press room at the Venice Film Festival has to be the most beautiful film festival press room in the world. Taking over the third floor of the imposing Palazzo del Casinò, the main atrium is a gargantuan, triple-height space carpeted in soft cream, with columns clad in marble extending up past Murano glass chandeliers, and floor-to-ceiling windows hung with gold-sheened drapes giving way to a sparkling blue sea. On a clear day — which it almost always is — you imagine that, were it not for the curvature of the earth, you could see forever. Or at least to Croatia.

author: By Will Heinrich
title: An Expansive Art History at the Independent Art Fair
description: In its second edition, the boutique fair’s 20th-century focus brings unseen masterpieces to New York.
content: For its second edition, again at the Battery Maritime Building at 10 South Street in Manhattan, the Independent 20th Century art fair — a spinoff of the contemporary-art-focused Independent — offers as dense a selection of top-shelf art as you’ll find this week. There are Warhol portraits (Vito Schnabel Gallery) and Picasso drawings (Perrotin), sure. But there are also tooled and dyed leather “paintings” by Winfred Rembert (James Barron Art), a solo presentation by the painter Peter Nadin overlooking the harbor (Off Paradise) and a number of historical artists rarely shown in New York or in the United States. As you’d expect from a high-end fair this rigorously curated and this small — just 50 artists showing in 33 booths — the exhibits are long on painting, the easiest medium to sell. But there are also sublime Southern Washoe style baskets by Louisa Keyser (Donald Ellis Gallery) and a group of spectacular early-20th-century totems from Vanuatu (Venus Over Manhattan), among other sculpture. What follow are the booths that particularly caught my eye, but the decisions weren’t easy. Getting in will cost you $45 at the door, but the information-chocked Online Viewing Room is free.
